shivkaari_cards.title: Understanding the Enemy
shivkaari_cards.description: Shivaji's wisdom in gathering intelligence before acting
shivkaari_cards.historical_value: Information is the foundation of strategy
shivkaari_cards.detailed_explanation: Before facing Afzal Khan, Shivaji spent months gathering intelligence through spies disguised as merchants, barbers, and helpers. This careful preparation was key to his victory. His network of informants provided crucial details about Afzal Khan's personality, weaknesses, and battle tactics.

shivkaari_cards.title: Strategic Preparation
shivkaari_cards.description: The importance of proper planning and resource management
shivkaari_cards.detailed_explanation: Shivaji ensured all forts were well-stocked with supplies and weapons. He commissioned special weapons including the famous waagh-nakha for the encounter. Every detail was planned, from escape routes to signal systems.

shivkaari_cards.title: Choosing the Battlefield
shivkaari_cards.historical_value: The wise leader fights on terms of their choosing
shivkaari_cards.detailed_explanation: By luring Afzal Khan to the hilly Javali valley, Shivaji neutralized the advantage of the enemy's superior cavalry and fought on familiar terrain. The Sahyadri mountains provided natural fortification and escape routes.

shivkaari_cards.title: Diplomatic Deception
shivkaari_cards.description: Using cunning and psychology in negotiations
shivkaari_cards.historical_value: Sometimes strategy requires appearing weaker than you are
shivkaari_cards.detailed_explanation: Shivaji's humble response to Afzal Khan's demands, sent through Gopinath Bokil, lulled the enemy into overconfidence while setting up the perfect trap. This psychological warfare was as important as physical preparation.

shivkaari_cards.title: Loyalty and Trust
shivkaari_cards.description: The bond between a leader and faithful companions
shivkaari_cards.historical_value: True strength lies in trusted allies
shivkaari_cards.detailed_explanation: Jiva Mahalya's instant response to protect Shivaji during the encounter shows the loyalty that great leaders inspire. 'Hota Jiva mhanoon vachla Shiva' became a famous saying celebrating this loyalty.

shivkaari_cards.title: Courage in Crisis
shivkaari_cards.historical_value: True courage is grace under pressure
shivkaari_cards.detailed_explanation: Despite facing a much larger and stronger opponent in close combat, Shivaji remained calm and executed his plan perfectly, showing no fear to Afzal Khan. This mental strength was crucial to his victory.

shivkaari_cards.title: Swift Victory
shivkaari_cards.description: The importance of decisive action when opportunity arises
shivkaari_cards.historical_value: Strike decisively when the moment is right
shivkaari_cards.detailed_explanation: The coordinated attack following the trumpet signals showed perfect timing and execution, turning a diplomatic meeting into a complete military victory. Every warrior knew their role and executed it flawlessly.

shivkaari_cards.title: Compassionate Leadership
shivkaari_cards.description: Showing mercy and honor even in victory
shivkaari_cards.historical_value: True leaders show strength through compassion
shivkaari_cards.detailed_explanation: After his victory, Shivaji showed respect for the fallen and concern for his people, demonstrating that great leaders fight to protect, not to destroy. This won him respect even from his enemies.

jagir.definition: A feudal land grant given by rulers to nobles in exchange for military service
jagir.context: Shivaji's jagir was the territory granted to the Bhosale family by the Adilshahi sultanate

sarnaubat.context: Netoji Palkar served as Shivaji's trusted Sarnaubat during the Afzal Khan campaign

waagh_nakha.definition: Tiger claws - a concealed weapon worn on fingers with sharp steel claws
waagh_nakha.context: Shivaji used waagh-nakha as his secret weapon during the encounter with Afzal Khan

shamiana.definition: A large decorative tent or marquee used for meetings and ceremonies
shamiana.context: The fateful meeting between Shivaji and Afzal Khan took place in a shamiana

watandar.definition: Hereditary village officials who held rights to land and local administration
watandar.context: Afzal Khan tried to bribe watandars from Shivaji's territory to switch sides

deshmukh.definition: Village headman or chief, responsible for revenue collection and local governance
deshmukh.context: Some Deshmukhs from Bhosale jagir submitted to Afzal Khan before the battle
